en.title: Ansible – Lesson 9: Variables in Ansible
en.subtitle: Understanding vars, register, facts and variable precedence

sections.heading: 1. What is a Variable in Ansible?
sections.content: A variable in Ansible is used to store a value that can change and be reused across playbooks and tasks.

sections.heading: 2. Why Variables are Important?
sections.content: Variables make playbooks dynamic, reusable and easy to manage instead of hardcoding values.

sections.heading: 3. Defining Variables in Playbook
sections.content: You can define variables using 'vars' inside the playbook.

sections.heading: 4. Variable Example
sections.content: Example: vars: app_name: nginx app_port: 80

sections.heading: 5. Using Variables in Tasks
sections.content: Use double curly braces to access variables: {{ app_name }}

sections.heading: 6. Variables from Inventory
sections.content: Variables can also be declared inside the inventory file for each host or group.

sections.heading: 7. Register Variables
sections.content: Register is used to store the output of a task into a variable for later use.

sections.heading: 8. Register Example
sections.content: Example: register: result — result.stdout can be used later.

sections.heading: 9. Ansible Facts
sections.content: Facts are system information automatically collected by Ansible such as OS, IP, memory and CPU.

sections.heading: 10. Accessing Facts
sections.content: Example: {{ ansible_hostname }}, {{ ansible_os_family }}

sections.heading: 11. Variable Precedence
sections.content: If the same variable is defined in multiple places, Ansible follows a priority order to decide which value to use.

sections.heading: 12. Common Variable Precedence Order
sections.content: Extra vars > Play vars > Inventory vars > Facts > Role defaults

sections.heading: Lesson 9 Summary
sections.content: You learned what variables are, how to define and use them, register outputs, facts and precedence.
